    • Appendix A: Proofs

    A. The Moment Problem and Its Solution

    Given a projection of order J ≥ 1 , the set of supporting physical probabilities P for projection M P ( R ) consists of all probability distributions P with the properties below (Curto and Fialko (1991), Theorem 5.1):
    1. The Hankel matrix
      H 0 ( P ) : = E t P R i + j 0 ≤ i , j ≤ J = E t P R J R J ′ (A1)
      is positive definite.
    2. The Hankel matrix
      H 1 ( P ) : = E t P R 1 + i + j 0 ≤ i , j ≤ J (A2)
      is positive semidefinite.

    B. Proof of Proposition 1

    Factorization 12 follows from the Vandermonde factorization of positive definite Hankel matrices (see, for example, Drmač (2015)). Constraint 1 J + 1 ′ H 0 ( P ) 1 J + 1 = 1 , where 1 J + 1 is a ( J + 1 ) -dimensional vector of ones, then implies that D is a diagonal matrix of strictly positive probabilities. In Vandermonde factorization 12, the distinct entries x 0 , x 1 , … , x J are defined by the roots of a uniquely determined polynomial of order J + 1 , with coefficients − ϕ 0 , − ϕ 1 , … , − ϕ J , 1 such that
    H 0 ϕ 0 ϕ 1 ⋮ ϕ J = H 1 e J + 1 , (A3)
    where e J + 1 is the ( J + 1 ) th unit vector in R J + 1 and H1 is defined in equation A2 above. Let e1 be the first unit vector in R J + 1 . As H1 is positive semidefinite under the assumptions of Appendix A for the truncated moment problem, Proposition 3.3 and Theorem 5.1 in Curto and Fialko (1991) imply that
    d J = V − 1 H 0 e 1 (A4)
    is a strictly positive ( J + 1 ) -atomic probability measure on support { x 0 , x 1 , … , x J } ⊂ ( 0 , ∞ ) , such that H 0 ( d J ) = H 0 ( P ) . Theorem 5.2 in Curto and Fialko (1991) finally implies that among any such representing measures, there is one such that H1 is singular.

    Appendix B: Implementation

    A. Tradeable Contracts in Detail

    To account for incomplete option markets with bounded moneyness domain [ a , b ] , we follow Schneider and Trojani (2014) and consider approximate payoff functions that are linearized outside of a corridor [ l , u ] containing [ a , b ] . For a general payoff function f, the corridor payoff is
    f [ l , u ] ( R ) : = f ( l ) + f ′ ( l ) ( R − l ) , R < l , f ( R ) , l ≤ R ≤ u , f ( u ) + f ′ ( u ) ( R − u ) , R > u . (B1)
    Corridor payoffs are tradeable using an extension of the Carr and Madan (2001) spanning result,41
    D f [ l , u ] ( R ) = ∫ l 1 f ′ ′ ( K ) ( K − R ) + d K + ∫ 1 u f ′ ′ ( K ) ( R − K ) + d K . (B2)
    In practice, this option portfolio is evaluated from a finite set of options with strikes l = K 1 < ⋯ < K n = 1 < K n + 1 < ⋯ < K N = u using the discrete approximation
    ∑ i = 1 n − 1 f ′ ′ ( K i ) ( K i − R ) + Δ K i + ∑ i = n N f ′ ′ ( K i ) ( R − K i ) + Δ K i ,
    where Δ K 1 = K 2 − K 1 , Δ K N = K N − K N − 1 , and Δ K i = ( K i + 1 − K i − 1 ) / 2 for 1 < i < N . This approximation is accurate for the strike range and density typically available in S&P 500 option markets.
    Our approach to recovery can be parameterized completely using a finite number of physical and forward-neutral moments of returns. We therefore focus on corridor approximations of the form
    f ( R ) ≈ f ( 1 ) + f ′ ( 1 ) ( R − 1 ) + D f [ l , u ] ( R ) (B3)
    for payoff functions generated by realized moments (powers) of returns. Since E t Q [ R ] = 1 , corridor divergence D [ l , u ] p ( R ) always has a finite forward price. In this case, the N D P ( p , 1 ) condition directly yields E t P [ D [ l , u ] p ( R ) ] < ∞ . More generally, the N D P ( p , n ) condition always implies E t P [ D [ l , u ] p ( R n ) ] < ∞ if the nth forward-neutral moment is finite.

    B. Vandermonde Factorization

    The Vandermonde factorization H 0 = V D V ′ in equation 12, where diagonal matrix D has strictly positive entries and matrix V is based on distinct parameters x 0 , x 1 , … , x J ⊂ ( 0 , ∞ ) , ensures that H0 is positive definite. This factorization comes with the additional benefit of delivering stable closed-form expressions for the determinant and the inverse of H0.42 From factorization 12, it follows that det ( H 0 ) = det ( D ) det 2 ( V ) , where det ( D ) = ∏ i = 0 J d i J and det ( V ) = ∏ 1 ≤ i < j ≤ J ( x i − x j ) . Inverses of Vandermonde matrices are computed efficiently with a closed-form and numerically stable LU decomposition using the closed-form expression for the determinant. An algorithm specifically designed for this purpose is available in Turner (1966). To compute the global MVP in our recovery approach, we minimize the HJ distance D ( d 3 ) with a differential evolution algorithm. Determinants of Hankel matrices H0 for projections of order J = 3 are on the order of 1e-12.

    Appendix C: Affine Models and Pricing Kernels

    In this appendix, we illustrate the properties of our minimum variance kernel recovery approach in the context of well-known arbitrage-free jump diffusion models, based on affine state dynamics with exponentially affine pricing kernels. For this purpose, denote by X a process on probability space ( Ω , F , ( F t ) t ≥ 0 , Q ) with values in D ⊂ R d and with semimartingale characteristics
    A t = ∫ 0 t a ( X s − ) d s , B t = ∫ 0 t b ( X s − ) d s , ν ( ω , d t , d ξ ) = K ( X t − ( ω ) , d ξ ) d t ,
    where a ( x ) , b ( x ) , and K ( x , d ξ ) are affine functions of state x
    a ( x ) = a + x 1 α 1 + ⋯ + x d α d , b ( x ) = a + x 1 β 1 + ⋯ + x d β d , K ( x , d ξ ) = m ( d ξ ) + x 1 μ 1 ( d ξ ) + ⋯ + x d μ d ( d ξ ) .
    Define for i ∈ { 1 , … , d }
    F ( y ) = 1 2 y , a y + b , y + ∫ R d ∖ 0 e ξ , y − 1 − h ( ξ ) , y m ( d ξ ) , (C1)
    R i ( y ) = 1 2 y , α i y + β i , y + ∫ R d ∖ 0 e ξ , y − 1 − h ( ξ ) , y μ i ( d ξ ) , (C2)
    with h ( ξ ) = 11 { | ξ | ≤ 1 } ξ . Furthermore, let
    D : = ∩ x ∈ D y ∈ R d : ∫ ξ ≥ 1 e y , ξ K ( x , d ξ ) < ∞ ,
    be the domain in which K has finite exponential moments. From Keller-Ressel and Mayerhofer (2015), the moment-generating function of X takes the form
    E Q e y , X t ∣ X 0 = x = e p ( t , y ) + q ( t , y ) , x , (C3)
    where p and q solve the ordinary differential equations
    ∂ ∂ t p ( t , y ) = F ( q ( t , y ) ) , p ( 0 , y ) = 0 , ∂ ∂ t q ( t , y ) = R ( q ( t , y ) ) , q ( 0 , y ) = y .

    A. Parametric Minimum Variance Kernels

    There are various possibilities for defining pricing kernels in affine models. We follow an exponentially affine approach that extends the pricing kernel specification in the introductory example of Section I. For any parameter θ ∈ D and t ≥ 0 , define the process (as in Keller-Ressel (2008) and Dai and Singleton (2000))
    M t ¯ θ : = d P θ d Q | F t = exp θ , X t − X 0 − t F ( θ ) − R ( θ ) , ∫ 0 t X s d s . (C4)
    This process is a Q martingale. Importantly, under probability P θ , process X is again affine with characteristics F θ ( y ) = F ( y + θ ) − F ( θ ) and R θ ( y ) = R ( y + θ ) − R ( θ ) . Furthermore, if the traded coordinates of X are Q martingales, then
    M t θ : = 1 M ¯ t θ = d Q d P θ | F t (C5)
    is a valid forward pricing kernel for horizons t > 0 .

    Example C1. (Black-Scholes power utility kernel)In a Black-Scholes model, F t , T : = e X t for any 0 ≤ t ≤ T and the univariate log forward process X solves the SDE

    d X s = − 1 2 σ 2 d s + σ d W s Q ; X 0 = x . (C6)
    The corresponding characteristics are
    F B S ( y ) = σ 2 y 2 2 − σ 2 y 2 , R B S ( y ) = 0 .
    For parameter θ = γ , the physical characteristics become
    F B S θ ( y ) = σ 2 y 2 2 + γ σ 2 y − σ 2 y 2 , R B S θ ( y ) = 0 ,
    along with the physical SDE
    dX s = γ − 1 2 σ 2 ds + σ d W s P θ ; X 0 = x . (C7)
    In this model, we recognize the P θ expected drift rate as γ σ 2 . Given T > 0 and r : = X T − X 0 , the Black-Scholes pricing kernel for horizon T is
    M γ , T B S = e − γ · r + γ σ 2 2 γ − 1 T , (C8)
    the typical normalized power utility kernel from the introduction in Section I. Since X is the only state variable in this economy and kernel C8 is r-measurable, this kernel agrees with its projection on R,
    M γ , T B S = E P [ M γ , T B S | R ] . (C9)

    Example C2. (Duffie, Pan, and Singleton ([2000]) double-jump diffusion model)For a more flexible model, consider a specification that solves the bivariate SDE

    d V s X s = κ v ( v ¯ − V s ) − λ ¯ μ ¯ − 1 2 V s d s + V s σ v 0 ρ 1 − ρ 2 d W s Q + d Z t Q , (C10)
    where F t , T = e X t as before, W Q is a bivariate Q-Brownian motion and d Z t Q is a compound Poisson counter in R 2 with constant mean arrival rate λ ¯ and a jump distribution that allows both cojumps and separate jumps in X and V. For equations C1 and C2, we specify43
    ∫ R 2 ∖ 0 e ξ , y − 1 m ( d ξ ) = λ ¯ ( Θ ( c 1 , c 2 ) − 1 ) , ∫ R 2 ∖ 0 e ξ , y − 1 μ i ( d ξ ) = 0 ; i = 1 , 2 ,
    where44
    Θ ( c 1 , c 2 ) : = λ v Θ v ( y 1 ) + λ y Θ x ( y 2 ) + λ c Θ c ( y 1 , y 2 ) λ ¯ , (C11)
    Θ v ( c ) : = 1 1 − μ v c , (C12)
    Θ x ( c ) : = exp μ x c + 1 2 σ x 2 c 2 , (C13)
    Θ c ( c 1 , c 2 ) : = exp μ x c 2 + 1 2 σ x 2 c 2 2 1 − μ v c 1 − ρ J μ v c 2 . (C14)
    Note that μ ¯ = Θ ( 0 , 1 ) − 1 for process e X t to be a martingale under Q. With this specification, we obtain
    F DPS ( y 1 , y 2 ) = y 1 v ¯ κ v − y 2 λ ¯ μ ¯ + λ ¯ ( Θ y 1 , y 2 − 1 ) , R DPS v ( y 1 , y 2 ) = − y 1 κ v + 1 2 2 ρ σ y 2 y 1 + σ 2 y 1 2 + y 2 2 − y 2 2 , R DPS x ( y 1 , y 2 ) = 0 .
    Using the parameterization θ = ( η , γ ) , we then have
    F DPS θ ( y 1 , y 2 ) = y 1 v ¯ κ v − y 2 λ ¯ μ ¯ + Θ η , γ λ ¯ Θ y 1 + η , y 2 + γ Θ η , γ − 1 , R DPS v , θ ( y 1 , y 2 ) = y 1 ( σ ( γ ρ + η σ ) − κ v ) + 1 2 2 ρ σ y 2 y 1 + σ 2 y 1 2 + y 2 2 + y 2 γ + η ρ σ − 1 2 , R DPS x , θ ( y 1 , y 2 ) = 0 .
    The physical state dynamics resulting from forward dynamics C10 is given by the SDE
    d V s X s = v ¯ κ v + ( σ ( γ ρ + η σ ) − κ v ) V s − λ ¯ μ ¯ + γ + η ρ σ − 1 2 V s ds + V s σ v 0 ρ 1 − ρ 2 dW s P θ + dZ s P θ .
    The physical average jump intensity is Θ ( η , γ ) λ ¯ and the physical jump-size distribution has moment-generating function Θ ( c 1 + η , c 2 + γ ) Θ ( η , γ ) .45

    Again, using the notation r : = X T − X 0 and parameter vector θ = ( 0 , γ ) , the pricing kernel for horizon T > 0 is given by

    M γ , T D P S = exp − γ · r + T F D P S ( 0 , γ ) + R D P S v ( 0 , γ ) ∫ 0 T V s d s . (C15)
    This pricing kernel depends on both the forward log return and the entire path of the variance process. Therefore, it is path-dependent and not r-measurable. Its finite-order projections on various realized moments of gross returns can be computed using the framework in this paper. More specifically, P and Q moments follow from the exponentially affine moment-generating function, which allows us to compute the model-based HJ projections consistent with equation 9.

    Figure IA.11 reports various MVP of order J = 3 for different conditioning values of the instantaneous variance and different pricing kernel parameters γ. We find that the shapes of these pricing kernel projections are relatively insensitive to the conditioning value of the instantaneous variance, despite the wide range of values for implied volatilities. In contrast, they are quite sensitive to the choice of the price of return risk parameterized by parameter γ.

    Example C3. (Song and Xiu ([2016]) model)This model is based on the following two-factor specification of forward dynamics

    d V s = η + κ ( ξ s − V s ) d s + σ V s d B s Q + J V Q d N s , d ξ s = α ( θ − ξ s ) d s + γ ξ d M s Q , d X s = − μ λ s + 1 2 V s d s + V s d W Q + J X Q d N s , (C16)
    where W Q and B Q are standard Brownian motions with correlation ρ, M Q is another independent Brownian motion, and J X Q and J V Q are random jump sizes with exponential and, respectively, double exponential distributions
    J V Q ∼ E ( β V ) ; J X Q ∼ E ( β + ) with probability q , E ( β − ) with probability 1 − q .
    The jump intensity λ t = λ 0 + λ 1 V t is stochastic and μ = E Q [ e J X Q − 1 ] . The P state dynamics in the model read
    d V s = η + κ ξ s − κ P V s d s + σ V s d B s P + J V P d N s , d ξ s = α θ − α P ξ s d s + γ ξ d M s P , d X s = μ 0 + μ 1 V s d s + V s d W P + J X P d N s , (C17)
    where W P and B P are standard Brownian motions with correlation ρ, M P is another independent Brownian motion, and J X P and J V P are random jump sizes with exponential and, respectively, double exponential distributions
    J V P ∼ E ( β V P ) ; J X P ∼ E ( β + P ) with probability q , E ( β − P ) with probability 1 − q .
    Also, for this specification, the P and Q moments follow from the exponential affine moment generating function, which is sufficient to compute the model-based MVP consistent with equation 9.

    Figure IA.10 plots various model-based MVP of order J = 3 for different pricing kernel parameter vectors θ = ( θ v , 0 , θ s ) . The shapes of these pricing kernel projections are relatively flexible, with monotonic, U-shaped, or inverse U-shaped projections that arise for various choices of vector θ. U-shaped projections typically obtain when volatility shocks are priced ( θ v > 0 ) and when return shocks have a relatively small price of risk ( θ s is small).

    B. Nonparametric Minimum Variance Kernels

    Given a forward probability Q, the previous section introduces a family of exponentially affine pricing kernels C5 and corresponding physical moment specifications that allow an explicit computation of a model-based finite-order MVP. More generally, given a finite set of forward moments, we can parameterize all admissible MVP of order J using Vandermonde representation 12. If the forward moments are model-based, this approach allows us to determine MVPs consistent with model-based forward moments without imposing additional structure on physical moments through a parametric pricing kernel specification.

    Clearly, any set of model-based physical moments is always supported by Vandermonde factorization 12. Therefore, model-based MVPs generally induce a higher pricing kernel variance than model-free MVPs under our approach because physical moments need to satisfy the model-implied parametric moment structure. Model-based constraints on the moment structure can be difficult to elicit and interpret, especially when several moments are simultaneously constrained, and they can have unexpected effects on the shape of MVPs. For instance, the bottom panel of Figure IA.9 shows that, even in the model of Duffie, Pan, and Singleton (2000) with exponentially affine pricing kernels, model-free MVPs can be U-shaped when the model-based MVPs are monotonic.
